resource.chars:
4. addend. to the note at p.319.
I thought it proper to add the following passage 
taken out of the Journal Book of the Royal 
Society, supposing it to be what Mr. Olden-
burgh hints at in his letter.
“Nov.16.1671. [Sr. Robert Moray] exhibited a 
“certain plant, (which was by Mr. Wray called 
“Lichen terrestris cinereus) said by Sr. Robert 
“Moray to be very good to cure <u>Dogs bitten 
“by mad Doggs<\u>: His Royal Highness having 
“caused it to be given to a whole Kennel of 
“Dogs, bitten by a mad one, <u>wch <\u> were all cured 
“except one of them, to whom none of it 
“was given.
the specimen was kept in the Repository.
The same Virtue is likewise ascribed to this 
Plant, In ye <u>III. Part. of Morison’s plantar.
histor. Oxon.<\u> published at <u>Oxford <\u> Anno 
1699. in folio, p. 632. where the Author 
speaking of the <u>Lichen terrestris cinereas <\u>
Raij hist. & Synops. says, <u>adversus morsum 
canis rabidi egregium est Medicamentum 
Dampier & the College of Physicians <\u> in their 
<u>Milv. Antilyssus <\u> prescribe equall Quantities 
of the <u>Lichen & pepper <\u>: but the Great <u>Dr. Mead <\u>
in a single <u>Quarto Leaf <\u> publish’d by him Anno 1735
hath alter’d the proportions of the composition, prescribing double
